body: Three years ago, Eileen McMillan sat at a kitchen table in Bergen Beach, Brooklyn, and stared blankly at her niece, Joan Tallerie. Ms. Tallerie was trying to talk to her aunt -- but wasn't getting much of a response. ''If we were standing next to her and we said something, she wouldn't even acknowledge us, she wouldn't look over or anything,'' Ms.
title: The Neediest Cases; A Set of Hearing Aids Reinvigorates One Life

body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. DOROTHY CHIARCHIARO A Kiss for Christmas It was Christmas Eve, 1962, and Nick Chiarchiaro was concluding a visit to his Aunt Betty in Park Slope, Brooklyn. He gave his cousin, Rose, a peck on the cheek -- when skinny Dorothy Arguelles, her friend, piped up:
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS; A Memorable Christmas Eve, a Girls' Night Out, and an Ideal Daughter

body: ON oceanfront land in Brooklyn once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, the Muss Organization of Queens is moving into the third year of construction on a condominium project that is reversing the symbolism of the site -- from one linked with the past to one reflecting the possibilities the city holds for its recent immigrants and their children.
title: On Brighton Beach, a Tide of Immigrants

body: A teenager accused last year of igniting a fire in a Brooklyn stable that killed 21 horses and sent 30-foot flames soaring into the night sky was acquitted yesterday by a state jury. The jury decided that the teenager, Frank Esposito, who was 17 at the time of the fire, was not guilty of arson, reckless endangerment and 21 counts of animal cruelty
title: Jury Acquits Teenage Boy In Stable Fire

body: A pretrial hearing is scheduled this morning in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn for Frank Esposito, a 17-year-old charged with setting a fire in the Bergen Beach Stables in June 2000 that killed 21 horses.
title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Fatal Stable Fire

body: There were marching bands and drum corps and a 20-piece steel drum ensemble, but the joyfullest noise of all along Surf Avenue in Coney Island yesterday emanated from the Dodger Sym-Phony, all five active survivors of it, and they brought tears to Judd Fischler's eyes. Forty-six years before, Fischler had been in another Brooklyn baseball parade, a
title: BASEBALL; It's Summer: The Boys Are Back in Town

body: For gangsters living the incognito life, the witness protection program can be as dull as old pencil lead. After all, wise guys love to talk, and under federal protection, whom do they really get to talk with except bartenders and waitresses at the local greasy spoon? It seems perfectly natural, then, that one relocated mobster should call another
title: Reporter's Notebook; What Mobsters Chat About: Glory Days and Bad Teeth

body: Surely one of the most suburban parts of Brooklyn is the wrench-shaped peninsula that holds Bergen Beach, Georgetown, Mill Basin and Old Mill Basin. This area is embroidered with shady, quiet streets and mint-green lawns; down by the water, houses can sell for $1 million and more. Historically, the area has been overwhelmingly white, and remains
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHEAST BROOKLYN; Drops of Diversity in a Quiet Area

body: In the recent battle over plans to let a private company manage five low-performing schools, the loudest and most effective voice belonged to Acorn, the community group that led the opposition. But few people who followed that battle seemed aware that Acorn has itself been involved in the New York City school system for more than a decade, helping
title: Mixed School Record for Edison Foes

body: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: MOTHER CHARGED IN BABY'S DEATH -- The mother of a baby whose body was found being eaten by a dog last week was charged last night in the child's death, officials said. The woman, Lisa Small, 16, was charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide. The city medical examiner's office determined that the baby had been
title: METRO BRIEFING
